Key Words: ST elevation MI, non-STE, ACS, cardiac biomarkers, treatment of ACS, mechanical complications of MI
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn how the admission ECG dictates early therapy for ACS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn how to use cardiac biomarkers to diagnose ACS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To become familiar with strategies for treatment in ACS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To become familiar with mechanical complications of ACS.
[LIST_ITEM] > 90% - plaque disruption with platelet aggregation → intracoronary thrombus
[LIST_ITEM] Continuum of ACS from unstable angina to STE MI
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Plaque Rupture Cholesterol content Inflammation (CRP, Mphage)
|  Unstable angina | Non-ST Elevation MI (Non-Q-wave MI) | ST-Elevation MI (Q-wave MI)  | | --- | --- | --- |
The continuum of acute coronary syndromes ranges from unstable angina, through non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (also referred to as “non-Q-wave” myocardial infarction
[MI]), to ST-elevation MI (also referred to as “Q-wave” MI).

[LIST_ITEM] Severe coronary artery spasm (primary or cocaine-induced)
[LIST_ITEM] Increased blood viscosity (e.g., polycythemia vera, thrombocytosis)
[LIST_ITEM] Significantly increased myocardial oxygen demand (e.g., aortic stenosis)

The continuum of acute coronary syndromes ranges from unstable angina, through non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (also referred to as “non-Q-wave” myocardial infarction
[MI]), to ST-elevation MI (also referred to as “Q-wave” MI).

|   | Unstable Angina | Myocardial Infarction  |   | | --- | --- | --- | --- | |   |  | NSTEMI | STEMI  | |  Typical symptoms | Crescendo, rest, or new onset severe angina | Prolonged “crushing” chest pain, more severe and wider radiation than usual angina  |   | |  Serum biomarkers | No | Yes | Yes  | |  ECG initial findings | ST depression and/or T wave inversion | ST depression and/ or T wave inversion | ST elevation (and Q waves later)  |
NSTEMI, non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (MI); STEMI, ST-elevation MI

[LIST_ITEM] Can be measured by serial blood testing
[LIST_ITEM] Pattern and level of rise correlates with timing and size of MI
[LIST_ITEM] Regulatory protein that controls interaction between actin & myosin
[LIST_ITEM] Unique cardiac troponins I and T exist - absent in serum of healthy people
[LIST_ITEM] Rise at 3-4 hours post-MI, peak 18-36 hrs, decline slowly 10-14 days
[LIST_ITEM] Enzyme that converts ADP to ATP
[LIST_ITEM] Found in many tissues: heart, brain, skeletal muscle, kidney, etc.
[LIST_ITEM] Can be elevated after injury to any of these tissues
[LIST_ITEM] Makes up much higher % of cardiac CK
[LIST_ITEM] Rises 4-8 hours after MI, peaks by 24 hours
[LIST_ITEM] GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor (for selected high risk patients; may be deferred until PCI)
[LIST_ITEM] Bivalirudin (should be used in ACS patient only if undergoing PCI)
ST-Elevation (STEMI) ↓ Emergent PCI available within 90 min?
No  Yes Fibrinolytic Therapy (e.g., tPA) Primary PCI
Non-ST-Elevation (UA and NSTEMI) ↓ Risk Assessment (e.g., GRACE Score)
Low  High Conservative Strategy (Proceed to cardiac cath only if recurrent angina or predischarge stress test is markedly positive)
Invasive Strategy (Cardiac cath leading to PCI or CABG)
[H1] Effect of ASA in Non-ST Elevation MI and Unstable Angina.
Incidence of Death or Subsequent MI
Meta-analysis Heparin + ASA vs. ASA alone
RR: Triple Endpoint (Death, MI/Recurrent Ischemia*) Day
*Definition of recurrent angina/urgent revasc differs between trials
[LIST_ITEM] Don’t give in patients with sx/ signs of heart failure
[LIST_ITEM] Urgent catheterization performed after initial medical Rx
[LIST_ITEM] Allows rapid identification & Rx of critical CAD
[LIST_ITEM] Cath patients with recurrent ischemia in hospital
[LIST_ITEM] Cath patients with inducible ischemia on pre-discharge stress test
[LIST_ITEM] Recent clinical trials show less infarction/ reinfarction & possibly death with invasive strategy
A degrade clot without systemic lytic state

[LIST_ITEM] Restore balance between $0_{2}$ supply and demand
[LIST_ITEM] Give immediately on presentation and daily thereafter
[LIST_ITEM] Give 1-2 days IV after PCI or lysis with tPA, rPA, or TNK-tPA... NOT SK
[LIST_ITEM] New anterior MI with large wall motion change
[LIST_ITEM] All others: SQ heparin while at bed rest to prevent DVT
[LIST_ITEM] Give IV, then orally unless contraindication exists (asthma, hypotension, significant bradycardia)
[LIST_ITEM] Reduce pulmonary congestion in heart failure
[LIST_ITEM] Esp. benefit anterior MI and/or LV dysfunction
[LIST_ITEM] Angina or ischemia confers increase risk for reinfarction
[LIST_ITEM] Should lead to angiography and revascularization for most pts.

[H1] Blood Supply in the Conduction System.

|  Conduction Pathway | Primary Arterial Supply  | | --- | --- | |  SA node | - RCA (70% of patients)  | |  AV node | - RCA (85% of patients)  | |  Bundle of His | - LAD (septal branches)  | |  RBB | - Proximal portion by LAD
[LIST_ITEM] Distal portion by RCA  | |  LBB |   | |  Left anterior fascicle | - LAD  | |  Left posterior fascicle | - LAD and PDA  |
[LIST_ITEM] Treated with vasodilators, diuretics, and Rx to reverse ischemia
[LIST_ITEM] Leads to acute mitral valve regurgitation
[LIST_ITEM] Rx: Coronary revascularization; IABP; valve repair
[LIST_ITEM] More likely in elderly, HTN, women
[LIST_ITEM] Occasional walls off to form pseudoaneurysm
[LIST_ITEM] Heralded by left to right shunting at ventricular level
[LIST_ITEM] More often in non-reperfused STE MI’s
[LIST_ITEM] More common in non-reperfused STE MI
[LIST_ITEM] Fever, sharp pain with pleuritic tendency, friction rub
[LIST_ITEM] Treatment: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent; heparin relatively contraindicated
[LIST_ITEM] Clot forms on infarcted akinetic myocardium
[LIST_ITEM] Most common in large anterior MI
[LIST_ITEM] If clot seen on echo or LVEF < 30% or if large anterior MI
[H1] Post MI Risk Stratification and Management.

|  Predictor of Poor Outcome | Method to Detect | Treatment  | | --- | --- | --- | |  Poor LVEF | Echocardiogram | ACE, BB  | |  Residual Ischemia | Pre D/C ETT | Cath; ASA,BB  | |   | Max ETT later |   | |  Arrhythmias | Monitoring/Observation | Directed  |
[LIST_ITEM] ACE for CHF; LVEF ≤ 40%, perhaps all
